instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-01521: What is 820-01521? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PP1V8_AWAKE: What is PP1V8_AWAKE? The PP1V8_AWAKE signal in the MacBook schematic is indicative of a power rail that delivers 1.8 volts when the machine is in an "awake" state. This is not a traditional power state defined in the older Intel PCH documentation; it seems to be specific to newer MacBook architectures. The "awake" designation likely refers to a state where the MacBook is on and ready for user interaction, but it is not necessarily at full operational capacity (which would be denoted by an S0 state).
definitions.CD3215: What is CD3215? This is a USB-C muxing chip responsible for USB-C communication with devices such as the laptop charger. The most common issue this chip is involved in is when a Macbook wonâ€™t charge or the charger is stuck at 5v instead of going to 20v..
definitions.PP3V3_G3H: What is PP3V3_G3H? PP3V3_G3H is a 3.3v power line that is present when the machine is in a Global System Hardware Off state, and should come on before most other rails so that the USB-C circuitry can be powered for the charger.
definitions.PP1V8_SLPS2R: What is PP1V8_SLPS2R? PP1V8_SLPS2R is a 1.8v power rail present when the system is in a SLPS2R state. .
definitions.PP3V3_G3H_RTC: What is PP3V3_G3H_RTC? PP3V3_G3H_RTC Is one of the first rails that has to come on in order for the USB-C mux chip to be powered in the T2 chip Macbook Pros..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01521</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>: Liquid Damage
threads.message:
First time working on one of these, oh boy (Late 2018 MacBook Air). 

Liquid hit in the <CHIP>U3200</CHIP>. One one USB-C port, 5v @ 0.001amp. The 2nd port would flash on/off/on/off. 

I replaced <CHIP>U3200</CHIP> and a couple of the small caps and resistors in that area that looked gross. Now, both USB-C ports show 5v @ 0.03amp, but occasionally it will flash on/off/on/off on the one port still. 

I'm getting my LDO outputs on both CD3215s. 

<SIGNAL>TBT_PWR_EN</SIGNAL> is 0v. Should I be following this or am I barking up the wrong tree?

Thanks in advance!

Jeff

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01521</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>: Liquid Damage
threads.message:
Check what happens with both charger and battery connected.
Do you get 1V1 LDO on both ports?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01521</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>: Liquid Damage
threads.message: Hmmm with everything plugged in, I'm getting 20.5v and 0.00a. T2 getting warm, nothing else that I can tell.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01521</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>: Liquid Damage
threads.message:
Why do not check for some board voltages now?
Battery has some charge?
Try to turn board on...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01521</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>: Liquid Damage
threads.message: Gah, I just came back to test this and it's back to 5.15v @ 0.01a, both ports.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01521</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>: Liquid Damage
threads.message: I'm getting 1.1v LDO line on both.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01521</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>: Liquid Damage
threads.message: Looks like more components affected by corrosion there.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01521</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>: Liquid Damage
threads.message: Coming back to this one. Things "look" clean. No broken traces that I can see, no really nasty components. Should I be hunting down <SIGNAL>TBT_PWR_EN</SIGNAL>?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01521</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>: Liquid Damage
threads.message:
Actual <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> voltage?
Do you get AWAKE and SLPS2R voltages?
Can you enter to DFU mode?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01521</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>: Liquid Damage
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> showing 12.3v, but seems to flicker down to 10v or 0v every few seconds. <SIGNAL>PP1V8_AWAKE</SIGNAL> is flickering between 0v and 0.7v.

No luck/signs of life trying to get into DFU mode.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01521</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>: Liquid Damage
threads.message:
On T2 boards, all voltages derive from <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>.
Check for short on secondary power supplies.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01521</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>: Liquid Damage
threads.message:
Coming back to this one, the "top" USB-C port isn't staying on. With the voltage reader plugged in the screen flickers on/off/on/off/on/off etc. The bottom port reads 5v 0.01amp. I replaced both <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP>.

I tried with a diff USB-C port piece and the top port started working. Put the original back... still working. This one is effing frustrating.

I'm still getting 12.3 on PPBUS. Using this list as reference: [URL]https://logi.wiki/index.php/T2_and_CD3215_Power_on_Sequence[/URL]

<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>: 12.3v
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H_RTC</SIGNAL>: 3.3v
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL>: 3.3v
<SIGNAL>PP1V8_SLPS2R</SIGNAL>: flickering between 0.00v and as high as 0.9v. It flickers up consistently every 0.5 seconds and then back to 0.00v. Checked restistance and it is shorted. Following this...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01521</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>: Liquid Damage
threads.message:
Which is the exact ohm value to ground at  <SIGNAL>PP1V8_SLPS2R</SIGNAL> ?


What about other AWAKE and SLPS2R voltages, any pulse at least?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01521</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>: Liquid Damage
threads.message:
In resistance mode: <SIGNAL>PP1V8_SLPS2R</SIGNAL> is 0.9ohm

I happened to get in a working board (yay!) and it is getting 4.5kohm. 

I injected shy of 3v and can't find the damn problem even using Flir. Lots of areas getting warm... but nothing on this line.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01521</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>: Liquid Damage
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01521</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>: Liquid Damage
threads.message: Well... yeah. I bumped it from 1.8 to 2.8 as nothing obvious was showing up... unwise judging from your response?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01521</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>: Liquid Damage
threads.message:
What kind of PSU used?
Did you leave the amp limit at max?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01521</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>: Liquid Damage
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01521</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>: Liquid Damage
threads.message:
You should get something like 2A ( a bit more) for 2v.
Something should heat with 4-5W.
Did you remove heatsink?
